raw_text:
Axa Sun Life cuts bonus payments
 
 Life insurer Axa Sun Life has lowered annual bonus payouts for up to 50,000 with-profits investors.
 
 Regular annual bonus rates on former Axa Equity & Law with-profits policies are to be cut from 2% to 1% for 2004. Axa blamed a poor stock market performance for the cut, adding that recent gains have not yet offset the market falls seen in 2001 and 2002. The cut will hit an estimated 3% of Axa's policyholders. The rest will know their fate in March.
 
 The cuts on Axa's policies will mean a policyholder who had invested £50 a month into an endowment policy for the past 25 years would see a final maturity payout of £46,998. This equated to a annual investment growth rate of 8% Axa said. With-profits policies are designed to smooth out the peaks and troughs of stock market volatility. However, heavy stock market falls throughout 2001 and 2002 forced most firms to trim bonus rates on their policies. "The stock market has grown over the past 18 months, however not enough to undo the damage that occurred during 2001 and 2002," Axa spokesman Mark Hamilton, Axa spokesman, told BBC News. Axa cut payouts for the same investors last January.
llama3.2:1b: Axa Sun Life cuts bonus payments on up to 50,000 with-profits investors due to poor stock market performance.
Regular annual bonus rates will be reduced from 2% to 1%.
The cuts affect estimated 3% of policyholders and policyholders who have invested £50 per month for 25 years.
llama3.2:3b: Axa Sun Life is cutting annual bonus payments on with-profits policies, reducing rates from 2% to 1% for 2004 due to poor stock market performance.
The cuts will affect an estimated 3% of policyholders and impact final maturity payouts.
gemma2:2b: Axa Sun Life is cutting annual bonus payments for with-profits policyholders by half.
The cut affects roughly 3% of Axa's policyholders and will reduce bonus rates from 2% to 1% for policies issued in 2004.
Axa blames the cuts on poor stock market performance, which resulted from heavy falls in 2001 and 2002.
The company said that recent gains haven't yet offset these losses.
This is not the first time Axa has made such a change, with a similar action taken last January.

tinyllama:1.1b: Axa Sun Life has lowered annual bonus payments for up to 50,000 with-profits investors by up to 1% for 2004.
The company cited poor stock market performance and a shift in the market's trends in its decision to cut bonus rates on these policies from 2% to 1%.
Regular payments averaging 2% were maintained for a group of investors, but will not be offered for those who had invested £50 per month for the past 25 years.

With-profits policies are designed to smooth out volatility in stock market returns and heavy stock market falls throughout 2001 and 2002 led to the reduction of bonus rates for these investors.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Cutting bonuses for with-profits policyholders at insurer Axa Sun Life is a move to compensate for poor stock market performance during recent years.
This decision comes as a result of a reevaluation by the company, which has decided to lower their annual bonus payments from 2% to 1%.
This decision affects around 3% of policyholders in total.
The cut would reduce the investment growth for these policyholders and could result in them receiving less than £50 at maturity for a 25-year endowment policy.
Axa Sun Life is a life insurer that offers policies designed to help protect investments during periods of market fluctuation, specifically during periods of high volatility.
The stock market has been struggling in recent years, with many companies reporting poor earnings and negative dividend growth.
This means investors may be more cautious and demand better returns on their investments than they were previously.
